name: Moonbase Alpha
description: NASA has once again landed on the lunar surface with the goal of colonization, research, and further exploration. Shortly after the return to the Moon, NASA has established a small outpost on the south pole of the moon called Moonbase Alpha.
minimum_requirements: Minimum OS: Win XP SP3 Processor: 2.0+ GHZ Single Core Processor  Memory: 2 GB of System RAM  Graphics: NVIDIA 7000-series or ATI Radeon X1900 Video Card  DirectX®: DirectX 9.0c  Hard Drive: 2 GB of Free Hard Drive Space  Sound: DirectX 9.0c compliant audio
recommended_requirements: Recommended OS: Win XP SP3 / Vista / Windows 7 Processor: 2.4+ GHz Dual Core Processor Memory: 4+ GB of System RAM Graphics: NVIDIA 9000+ or ATI Radeon 3600+ Video Card DirectX®: DirectX 9.0c  Hard Drive: 5 GB of Free Hard Drive Space

Moonbase Alpha is a marvel of the 21st century. You cannot even compare any other games like Gears of War, Call of Duty, Team Fortress 2, or even Assassin's Creed to this landmark in human intelligence. If you were to put a average Joe into this kind of enviroment, his head would implode from the amazing graphics, story, and gameplay. If you were to play this game, your feeble monkey brain would not even be able to understand the deep, complex and twisted story of Moonbase Alpha. NASA's masterpiece of 2010 shows us how far America has come in understanding space and lifestyle in space. Moonbase Alpha shows that even through NASA, we can learn much more about space and the human psyche. Moonbase Alpha follows the story of astronaut John Madden and his daily life on Moonbase Alpha, NASAs experimental base on the moon. If John fails his secret mission objective, his family and status in the NFL will be taken away and soiled by NASA. Moonbase Alpha brings us this harrowing story along with intense gameplay elements such as fixing carbon dioxide leaks, repairing solar panels, and driving robots. If you even attempted to finish such a hard, cruel game, you would be hailed as a god among men. Jesus would bless you with immortality and wealth beyond comprehension. The graphics in Moonbase Alpha top even Crysis 3 and have made many a computer catch fire. Even my IBM Super Computer cannot handle such a masterpiece as Moonbase Alpha. Many will look back to this game in the future, and smile as they remember their glorious past. NASA will forever be hailed as the wunderkind of this millenia. Thank you, NASA, for creating such a wonderful and exciting game.

Moonbase Alpha is a very realistic game. You can create your own servers to play with your friends. There isn't a large objective to the game, but the feature with the typing-to-voice is something that I haven't seen before. There are many unique things about this game, such as the 3D solids implemented into this. This game reminds me of Gene Endrody's Moonbase (by Maid Marian). If you enjoy anything involving space travel and just a casual mmorpg, this is a great game to start.

There may have been updates since I last played this, however the version I installed was an interesting little simulator. There was some educational value to be had, but not much. The game play is also not very intuitive and could benefit from tutorials. The game seemed to be very stable, however it had issues in multiplayer missions due to children constantly attempting to grief players by undermining the work of those attempting to accomplish the mission within the allotted time limit. If there was more content, specifically missions, or perhaps there was a sandbox mode available during Alpha in which players could use to simply build with, this would have real value. As it is, it's simply a toy for wasting time.  I am recommending this for younger children or anyone who has an interest in real life space exploration, as these are the individuals most likely to enjoy this. That said, I do not think it will be able to keep anyones attention for very long unless content is added.

'MoonLog Entry #123xFF: We've been held prison on this rock for 9 months now. I don't know how things could've gone so wrong with the AI development program. We began testing their motor-skill coordination with an old Sega Genesis and a copy of 'Madden NFL '95.' They became obsessed! Any moment free from performing maintainence tasks they spent playing that outdated video simulation. We started finding large rocks arranged in the shape Johns Madden's portrait. We thought this behavior was harmless....but we were wrong. The droids went rampant! 'JOHN MADDEN! JOHN MADDEN!', they howled. They demanded to see their football god; a demand that we had no means to satisfy. Lt. Jenkins immediately made a run for the airlock, but was promptly shot through the skull with a mining laser. 'AEIOU!', they shrieked. We're been held captive in our own base until their demands are met. Conner predicts that our life support will only last for 5 more weeks. God help us all.'

The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) is an independent agency of the executive branch of the United States Federal Government responsible for the civilian space program as well as aeronautics and aerospace research.[note 1]  President Dwight D. Eisenhower established NASA in 1958[7] with a distinctly civilian (rather than military) orientation encouraging peaceful applications in space science. The National Aeronautics and Space Act was passed on July 29, 1958, disestablishing NASA's predecessor, the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA). The new agency became operational on October 1, 1958.[8][9]  Since that time, most US space exploration efforts have been led by NASA, including the Apollo moon-landing missions, the Skylab space station, and later the Space Shuttle. Currently, NASA is supporting the International Space Station and is overseeing the development of the Orion Multi-Purpose Crew Vehicle, the Space Launch System and Commercial Crew vehicles. The agency is also responsible for the Launch Services Program (LSP) which provides oversight of launch operations and countdown management for unmanned NASA launches.  NASA science is focused on better understanding Earth through the Earth Observing System,[10] advancing heliophysics through the efforts of the Science Mission Directorate's Heliophysics Research Program,[11] exploring bodies throughout the Solar System with advanced robotic spacecraft missions such as New Horizons,[12] and researching astrophysics topics, such as the Big Bang, through the Great Observatories and associated programs.[13] NASA shares data with various national and international organizations such as from the Greenhouse Gases Observing Satellite.

Since the dawn of time, mankind has dreamed of walking on sunshine. Now, the next best thing is possible. Moonbase Alpha uses realistic NASA approved science to flawlessly recreate the excitement of routine moon upkeep, moon driving, moonwalking, and moon mooning, all accentuated by the breathtaking grey desert that is the Earth's moon as a backdrop. The money NASA put into this game can be considered a cause for its eventual discontinuation of the space program, so why not turn a national tragedy into a fun filled 45 minutes with you and 2 or 3 friends you've tricked into playing.

You are given a time limit to complete the objective and you have to work together with people to get it done on time. Then, after you do that, you repeat that same mission.... Again... This is it really for the review and do I recommend this game? Hell Yes. You go NASA!

Horribly unbalanced, making most of the tools useless -- there is only one set way/process to get the fastest time. NASA, how do you ever expect keep us (the competitive MA community) when the balance is so terrible?  -The robot, even on lowest battery and highest speed, has way too much power. -Tools such as markers are useless. -Glitches on vehicles makes your team insta-lose. -Animation problems and awkward collision lengthens your time by ~10-20s+ each run. -Terrible matchmaking. You thought DOTA2 or LoL was bad? Literally EVERYONE in every public server I've joined are noobs who probably couldn't even finish a run in the lowest tier of time, and just play around with the voice feature.  I've tried very hard to keep my MAR (Moonbase Alpha Rating) even at default levels, but all these noobs are ruining every single run for me. Some go as far as body-blocking me, or stealing the equipment that I'm using, and pretty much everyone spams the chat and abuses the voice feature, instead of using it to save the valuable time that it takes to type while communicating with your team. With no mods to ban these griefers, I don't think ANY serious MA player could last long in such a terrible environment.  If this keeps up, I might as well go back to Moon Base by Maid Maian.

When me and my mates first got into the game, we didn't realize what we had stepped into. However the adventure that awaited us was long, and arduous. In the first chapter, you must pick a random player from a lobby, and tell him he is 'The Chosen One' who's destiny is to Slay John Madden, and save the moon. After this, we would bring the Chosen One an Excalibur Blade (or beacon). When John Madden comes to destroy the moon, the chosen one must slay him with all his might. After John Madden was stopped, Chapter 2 is started. In which, you must save the enslaved worms from their holding cells. By unplugging them, and taking them all to their homes. Once you do that, the chosen one gets all the babes, and you win the game.  10/10 Needs a sequel.  #SaveTheWormz

Once some of the New maps start coming I know Ill be coming back to launch off to another distant horizon. This one completely threw a wrench in it for me the first time I went online with someone. Firstly I had no idea that outter space not only can noone hear you 'scream' , but theres no sound at all i guess. So I completely just said 'meh' and walked out of the lobby. But it took only a second chance encounter with this game that now has me buckled down and ready for some actual flight to someplace.  Urnfortunately this one is mostly taking place on the ground as a techie astronaut that has to solve the issues of scientists stranded upon our one planet that weve set foot on other than our own. The concept is simple in that you have to load up your equipment onto a moon buggy and head on out and pull a bruce willis but instead of dissolving a humongous asteroid into pieces, you just have to save a few stranded persons inside their small space huts up on that white moon. The slowness of the whole mission(s) are almost too tedious at first that is until you strap into the moon buggy and start your journey to start problem - solving. THats what this one is about so mostly it tends to attract us mechanics, pc fixer-uppers, and an occasional baker or two. Ha. Well the tool kits you use are very basic, but the parts you get to change out make this one intersting enough, specially for you weekend mechanics. The wrench came in handy for me only a couple times(But your remote robot will use it in the dastardly deeds and danger prone environments). This is also where some of you may be still entertained enough to want to finish the 'Mission : The robot you get off the main base hq, you assemble in a matter of seconds with a funny little animation sequence. But the operationality of it all is where the frustration among other things soon starts. The little wheels attached to the robot have to be slightly manipulated just enough to get where you want(dont even try backwards unless you like using a stopwatch for literally the slowest backup in historical history of moon buggy inventions).  Next comes the repairing jobs, its fun once you figure what needs repairing, and you just have to use a {Welding gun' and A 'Wrench' both for you and your bots. However theres also a matter of Battery Juice runing out quite quickly for you armchair astronauts. THERE IS NO RECHARGABLE BATTERIES, YET! You have to either Disassemble the whole contraption, or just completely make it go away and get a new one. This comes in handy in that you get a fresh robot, but frustrating for you folks who like to come back and finish what you started in your Weekend Tool Shed.  Also you get to change out parts and various things like : Satellite dishes, and Solar Panels and an occasional Hose. But usually a welding torch or wrench suffices. I know Ill be back to venture back for NASA once they head out to MARS and maybe Venus if theres some opposite sex on that distant planet. Ha

Moonbase Alpha is a marvel of the 21st century. You cannot even compare any other games like Gears of War, Call of Duty, Team Fortress 2, or even Assassin's Creed to this landmark in human intelligence. If you were to put a average Joe into this kind of enviroment, his head would implode from the amazing graphics, story, and gameplay. If you were to play this game, your feeble monkey brain would not even be able to understand the deep, complex and twisted story of Moonbase Alpha. NASA's masterpiece of 2010 shows us how far America has come in understanding space and lifestyle in space. Moonbase Alpha shows that even through NASA, we can learn much more about space and the human psyche. Moonbase Alpha follows the story of astronaut John Madden and his daily life on Moonbase Alpha, NASAs experimental base on the moon. If John fails his secret mission objective, his family and status in the NFL will be taken away and soiled by NASA. Moonbase Alpha brings us this harrowing story along with intense gameplay elements such as fixing carbon dioxide leaks, repairing solar panels, and driving robots. If you even attempted to finish such a hard, cruel game, you would be hailed as a god among men. Jesus would bless you with immortality and wealth beyond comprehension. The graphics in Moonbase Alpha top even Crysis 3 and have made many a computer catch fire. Even my IBM Super Computer cannot handle such a masterpiece as Moonbase Alpha. Many will look back to this game in the future, and smile as they remember their glorious past. NASA will forever be hailed as the wunderkind of this millenia. Thank you, NASA, for creating such a wonderful and exciting game.

I almost rated this game down. But then I realized the little gleam of hilarity that makes this game oh so worthwile.  Just the sheer awkwardness of this game is charming. Men walking around on that little rock that rotates around our wonderful world, just goofing off and working on sustaining a moonbase (or completely ruining that bases operational capabilites).  The first thing people do when they actually go into a game is either one of two things; You are there to make a fool of yourself (along with everyone else, so there is no ridicule), or take the game seriously. The former is more likely done than the latter, most likely because nearly nobody takes this game seriously. A must do for this game is enable the text to speech, and you will most likely NEVER do that latter ever again, or never even consider it at that point, as the TTS reads all messages just in such janky and funny matter.  A usual game of Moonbase Alpha looks like this: - The jerkoffs that lollygag around the base (nearly everyone). - Serious players. - 'AEIOU' TTP spammers.  This game is an accidental gem. For being free, such a seemingly boring experience could be easily reversed into a hilarious and completely nonsensical game. Should not be played for extended periods of time, may lose brain cells.  //   Should not be played for extended periods of time, players may lose brain cells. [i/] \\

Pros:  -The Text-To-Speach system is one of the most fun I have ever seen, trolling people with it it very fun. -You can be John Madden, or meet John Madden... -2 'Gamemodes' to choose from, one team, or two teams with a halloween twist, gameplay is otherwise the same. -You can disable the Text-To-Speach or host a password protected server with a friend if you don't like the spam.  Cons: -Old-ish game, 2010. -Less than an hour of actual 'gameplay' other than messing about with stuff. -People can kill your ears and/or sound equipment using chat macros such as [:nh][:rate0][:dv br 80][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>] -The gameplay that does exist, is very repetitive though still fun the first 4 or so times. -The base is more or less premade for you, nothing you can customnise.  tl;dr Fun game, say [:nh][:rate0][:dv br 80][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>][iy<9000047>] in chat to murder your friend or entire server.

Couldn't even get past the first level (if it's even level based, it could just be an endless series of coupling failures). Essentially, this game asks the question Kerbal Space Program forgot: how will you survive once you get to the moon? And then it applies Murphy's Law and makes it all go horribly wrong. 8/10, the fact NASA made it is pretty cool, and it has nice music too, just a lot more intense and unforgiving than I expected it to be.

A very small and enjoyable game that puts you on a specific Moon Base, on this base you are aquired with one objective with many obstacles... To fix the oxygen, it took me almost a hour to figure out how to use this game the right way, and it was upmost enjoyable, I got to take a look at how it would really be like to be in a sire situation on the moon, and how to fix the problem. What I like about this game is all three things I've came up with, how utterly hilarious it can be, how challenging the game is, and the fact that NASA formed this game. The game puts in a Text - Speech system, which means, what you type turns into voice (or what your astronaut says), and when you play with a couple friends, it's hilarious, you can say different things that just make you crack up in laughter and never stop for some odd reason. I can't stress enough on how it took me 20 minutes to figure out that a tube goes into a dispencer. Type. Thing... But on topic, this game can make you look like you've just graduated from Pre-School, there are many steps to go along until you complete the one objective for oxygen... And boy does it hurt your head just completing it. The fact that NASA, USA's lead Astronaut and Aerospace Research company, made a game to give to the whole public, and the fact that they made the things that sounded like rocket science into simple topics that a 7 year old can figure out... If it understood that the pipe goes into the dispencer thingy. This game is recommended for playing with friends mostly cause it's not that much fun if you can't use the Text - Speech and make people laugh while doing it, recommended for all people :D
